key_points: Pauline Bauer, a restaurant owner from Kane, Pennsylvania, faced backlash after her arrest for participating in the Capitol riot on Jan. 6.
Bauer and longtime friend William Blauser Jr. are among those charged for storming the Capitol, leading to partisan bickering in their hometown.
Bauer was recorded shouting at police during the riot to bring out Nancy Pelosi to be hanged.
Despite the controversy, Bauer claims her actions haven't harmed her friendships or business, with regular customers still supporting her.
The division over the Capitol riot reflects broader political splits, with significant differences in views across party lines.
Bauer and Blauser were arrested in May; video evidence shows them entering the Capitol and participating in the riot.
In Kane, a town that strongly supported Trump in the 2020 election, many still display pro-Trump signs.
Bauer, who became outspoken against COVID-19 lockdown measures, has embraced ideologies aligned with the sovereign citizens movement.
Blauser, advised to avoid Bauer, continues to support her, highlighting their friendship.
The cases of those charged in the Capitol riot are proceeding, with some already pleading guilty or being sentenced.
spokespersons: Joe Lanich (Owner, The Laughing Owl Press Co.)
